title: 113_hr4873
content:
The "Cabin Fee Act of 2014" may be cited as the official title. It pertains to cabin user fees. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish a fee for special use permits on National Forest System land for recreational residence purposes. An interim fee will be assessed until the current appraisal cycle is completed, with the fee being the lesser of the amount determined under the Cabin User Fees Fairness Act or $5,600. The Secretary is required to complete the current appraisal cycle within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary will complete the current appraisal cycle for recreational residences on National Forest System land in accordance with the Cabin User Fees Fairness Act. Only approved appraisals during this cycle will establish the base value for lots, with adjustments as needed. The Secretary will adjust the value of appraised lots with recreational residences based on the 4th quarter of 2012 National Association of Homebuilders/Wells Fargo Housing Opportunity Index. An annual fee will be assessed for recreational residences on National Forest System land following a tiered fee structure. The fee for recreational residences on National Forest System land is based on a tiered fee structure, ranging from $600 to $5,600, with percentages varying from 1% to 26% nationally. The Secretary adjusts annual fees based on changes in the Implicit Price Deflator for the Gross Domestic Product. Criteria are established for temporarily suspending or reducing fees if access or occupancy is restricted. Cabin owners have the right to appeal fee determinations. Periodic reviews are conducted every 10 years. The Secretary periodically reviews annual fees to ensure fair value for land use, considering all limitations and restrictions. Recommendations for modifying the fee system may be included in the report submitted to Congress every 10 years. Appraisals are not required for fee system modifications based on the Secretary's recommendations. SEC. 3. CABIN TRANSFER FEES.

The Secretary will set a $1,200 fee for issuing a new recreational residence permit due to ownership change, adjusted annually based on economic indicators.

SEC. 4. EFFECT.

This Act does not limit U.S. rights to land in the National Forest System. In Alaska, fees must align with existing laws.

SEC. 5. RETENTION OF FEES. SEC. 5. RETENTION OF FEES.

Beginning 10 years after enactment, the Secretary can keep fees collected under this Act for program administration on National Forest System land.

SEC. 6. REPEAL OF CABIN USER FEES FAIRNESS ACT OF 2000.

The Cabin User Fees Fairness Act of 2000 is repealed upon the assessment of annual permit fees.
